title: Korah's Rebellion
shortSummary: Numbers 16 recounts the rebellion of Korah, Dathan, and Abiram against Moses and Aaron's divinely appointed leadership. The chapter demonstrates God's judgment on pride and rebellion, affirming the holiness and authority of the priesthood and leadership established by God. It serves as a solemn warning against challenging God's chosen servants and the sacred order He has ordained.
timeline: c. 1446 BC - Wilderness Journey after the Exodus

keyCharacters.name: Korah
keyCharacters.description: A Levite who led a rebellion against Moses and Aaron, challenging their leadership and priestly authority.

keyCharacters.name: Moses
keyCharacters.description: The God-appointed leader of Israel who intercedes for the people and confronts the rebellion.

keyCharacters.name: Aaron
keyCharacters.description: Moses' brother and the high priest, whose priestly role is challenged by Korah and his followers.

keyCharacters.name: Dathan and Abiram
keyCharacters.description: Sons of Eliab from the tribe of Reuben who joined Korah's rebellion and refused to appear before Moses.

definitions.definition: A vessel used to burn incense, symbolizing prayer and worship offered before the LORD.
The office and role of those set apart to minister before God, especially in offering sacrifices and interceding for the people.
Set apart, consecrated, and dedicated to God; morally pure and distinct from the common or profane.
The act of making amends or reparation for sin, often through sacrifice or intercession, to restore fellowship with God.

outline.heading: The Rebellion of Korah and His Followers
outline.description: Korah, Dathan, Abiram, and 250 leaders challenge Moses and Aaron, claiming that all Israel is holy and questioning the exclusive leadership roles. Moses responds by seeking God's judgment to reveal His chosen servants.

outline.heading: The Test of the Censers
outline.description: Moses instructs the rebels to present censers with incense before the LORD to demonstrate who He has chosen. The glory of the LORD appears, signaling divine presence and impending judgment.

outline.heading: God's Judgment on the Rebels
outline.description: God commands separation from the rebellious congregation. The earth opens and swallows Korah, Dathan, Abiram, and their households, while fire consumes the 250 men offering unauthorized incense, confirming God's judgment on rebellion.

outline.heading: The Consecration of the Censers
outline.description: God instructs that the censers of the sinners be made into a covering for the altar as a lasting sign to Israel that only Aaron's descendants may offer incense, reinforcing the sanctity of the priesthood.

outline.heading: The Aftermath and Plague
outline.description: Despite the judgment, the people murmur against Moses and Aaron, resulting in a plague that kills 14,700. Aaron intercedes with incense to stop the plague, highlighting the power of priestly intercession and God's mercy.

application: Respect and submit to God-ordained leadership, recognizing that rebellion against His appointed servants is rebellion against God Himself.
Approach God with reverence and holiness, understanding that sacred roles and worship practices are established by divine authority.
Trust in God's justice and mercy, knowing He will judge sin but also provides a way for atonement through intercession and obedience.
Guard against pride and entitlement, remembering that all believers are called to humility and submission within God's order.

keyVerses.text: And he spake unto Korah and unto all his company, saying, Even to morrow the LORD will shew who are his, and who is holy; and will cause him to come near unto him: even him whom he hath chosen will he cause to come near unto him.
keyVerses.significance: This verse highlights God's sovereign authority to choose His servants and affirms the holiness required to approach Him.

keyVerses.text: And it came to pass, as he had made an end of speaking all these words, that the ground clave asunder that was under them:
keyVerses.significance: God's dramatic judgment against Korah and his followers confirms the seriousness of rebellion and the holiness of His appointed leadership.

keyVerses.text: To be a memorial unto the children of Israel, that no stranger, which is not of the seed of Aaron, come near to offer incense before the LORD; that he be not as Korah, and as his company: as the LORD said to him by the hand of Moses.
keyVerses.significance: This verse serves as a solemn reminder of the sanctity of the priesthood and the consequences of unauthorized worship.

keyVerses.text: And he stood between the dead and the living; and the plague was stayed.
keyVerses.significance: Aaron's intercession demonstrates the power of priestly mediation and God's readiness to show mercy upon repentance.
